OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES-RELEVANTES: My research combines environmental and bioarchaeology, encompasses both fieldwork and laboratory science and focuses on human-environmental interaction in eastern South American, in Mediterranean areas and in the NW Europe. My research is mainly focused on: ? Human-faunal interaction in NW Europe. I am particularly interested in the societal significance of chickens, from its early dispersal in NW Europe to its crucial position in providing food security to past populations. ? How important were coastal resources to past hunter-gatherers. My research involve seasonal studies on mollusc shells and palaeodietary reconstruction using stable carbon and nitrogen isotopes of bulk collagen ? Palaeoclimatic reconstructions using environmental records preserved in archaeological deposits. My research involve stable carbon and oxygen isotope analysis of terrestrial mollusc shells

SETORES-DE-ATIVIDADE.SETOR-DE-ATIVIDADE-1: Atividades ligadas ao patrimnio cultural e ambiental

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES:
In 2011 I joined to the Department of Archaeology of the University of York. Here, at the BioArCh I worked as a Marie Curie Postdoctoral Research Fellow (EU-IEF) on an interdisciplinary project involving isotopic and molecular analysis of human, faunal and artefact remains from middle-late Holocene shell middens (Sambaqui) of Brazilian coast (COREBRAS project).
http://cordis.europa.eu/projects/rcn/98650_en.html

LINHA-DE-PESQUISA.TITULO-DA-LINHA-DE-PESQUISA: South American archaeology, Mediterranean archaeology, coastal archaeology stable isotope, molecular analysis, archaeozoology, palaeodiet

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Changing Cultural and Scientific Perspectives of Human-Chicken Interactions
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Chickens (also known as 'domestic fowl') are native to South East Asia but, today, they have a worldwide distribution. Their diffusion is almost entirely due to human-assisted transportation and, as such, their natural history is a reflection of human history.
Considerable attention has been given to charting the chicken?s eastward spread from Asia, through the Pacific islands to the Americas; however, the species? diffusion to the west, through India, the Near East, Mediterranean and northern Europe, has been almost completely neglected: no genetic work has been undertaken and the timing and circumstances of their spread remains poorly understood.
Given the social significance of this species (whether as a provider of foodstuffs, their widespread use in cock-fighting or within magic and medicine) and their growing popularity as domestic pets, a detailed analysis of their natural and cultural history in the West is long overdue.
Such a study has the potential to inform on poultry-borne diseases, food security and environmental ethics, issues of particular importance at a time when billions of people rely on mass-produced chickens as a source of sustenance.
This project brings together researchers from a wide range of countries and disciplines - archaeology, anthropology, (art) history, biology, cultural geography, ecology, human-animal studies, philosophy, theology - to examine the social, cultural and environmental impact of this important but under-researched species.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES:
Chickens (also known as 'domestic fowl') are native to South East Asia but, today, they have a worldwide distribution. Their diffusion is almost entirely due to human-assisted transportation and, as such, their natural history is a reflection of human history.
Considerable attention has been given to charting the chicken?s eastward spread from Asia, through the Pacific islands to the Americas; however, the species? diffusion to the west, through India, the Near East, Mediterranean and northern Europe, has been almost completely neglected: no genetic work has been undertaken and the timing and circumstances of their spread remains poorly understood.
Given the social significance of this species (whether as a provider of foodstuffs, their widespread use in cock-fighting or within magic and medicine) and their growing popularity as domestic pets, a detailed analysis of their natural and cultural history in the West is long overdue.
Such a study has the potential to inform on poultry-borne diseases, food security and environmental ethics, issues of particular importance at a time when billions of people rely on mass-produced chickens as a source of sustenance.
This project brings together researchers from a wide range of countries and disciplines - archaeology, anthropology, (art) history, biology, cultural geography, ecology, human-animal studies, philosophy, theology - to examine the social, cultural and environmental impact of this important but under-researched species.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: COASTAL RESOURCES AND SOUTH AMERICAN HUNTER-GATHERERS: BIOCHEMICAL PERSPECTIVES FROM BRAZILIAN SAMBAQUIS (COREBRAS)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
In the last decade there has been an explosion of interest into the role played by coastal ecosystems in the lives of hunter-gatherers. Studies have highlighted the importance of ecological, physical and climatic conditions of coastal areas on the biological evolution, dispersion, survival and social development of earliest humans. This new research direction offered more nuanced investigations: how important are coastal resources for humans with a shared cultural identity but living in different ecosystems? Do the social response to different coastal habitats changes over space and time?
COREBRAS project aims to address these interrogatives to South America archaeology and specifically to Brazilian sambaquis. Sambaquis are cultural shell middens left by hunter-gatherer-fishers (HGF) that inhabited Brazilian coasts between ca. 8-1 ka BP. They represent the world's largest evidence of prehistoric reliance on coastal resources. By undertaking these interrogatives, COREBRAS will provide new skills on human ecology and on the global role of coastal areas in the complex humankind's adaptation to different environmental and climate conditions.
COREBRAS will for the first time transfer scientific knowledge from European developments in biomolecular archaeology to Brazilian issues by mean of an extensive program of analysis on sambaquis (Human, fauna and artefact remains). With this aims I will exploit the remarkable concentration of expertise at the University of York (UK), the world's leader in biomolecular archaeology. The proposed project represents a unique opportunity for cross-European integration of the study of one of the major forms of prehistoric site. The trained I will receive at the BioArCh group (University of York) in different biomolecular techniques will provide me multiple skills and competences to face objectives of COREBRAS project and enhance my interdisciplinary career opportunity within and outside the European scientific community.
http://cordis.europa.eu/search/index.cfm?useaction=proj.document&PJ_RCN=11957886

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: COASTAL RESOURCES AND SOUTH AMERICAN HUNTER-GATHERERS: BIOCHEMICAL PERSPECTIVES FROM BRAZILIAN SAMBAQUIS (COREBRAS)

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: COLONESE, A. C.;COLONESE, ANDR C.;COLONESE, ANDR CARLO;COLONESE, A.C.;COLONESE, ANDRE CARLO;COLONESE, ANDR C.

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: My postdoctoral research at the CSIC (IMF, Barcelona) focused on understanding environmental impacts on prehistoric coastal populations, with current research in South, Central American and the Mediterranean region. Since my PhD in Earth Science-Prehistory at the University of Siena I have been fortunate to work in some world renowned labs in Italy (Earth Science and Archaeology, University of Siena, University of Florence and University of Pisa), Spain (Ethnoarchaeology, Autonomous University of Barcelona and Spanish National Research Council at Barcelona) and in UK (Archaeology and Geochemistry, University of York and SUERC). During my four years of postdoctoral experience I developed an extensive network with researchers from these academic and scientific institutions. Three main research lines were carried out during the previous postdoctoral experience. These were i) the study of Hunter-gatherer-fisher (HGF) in low productive coastal areas (Mediterranean basin), II) the study of Ethnographic HGF in coastal areas (Tierra del Fuego, Argentina) and iii) geochemical analysis of land snail shell remains. These research lines are highly interdisciplinary (involving humanities, social and natural sciences) and offered a realistic opportunity to consolidate collaborations between departments and with international institutions. As results I completed several research projects and publications in books, conferences and in peer reviewed international journals (ISI Web of Science e.g. Journal of Quaternary Science, Global and Planetary Change, Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology, Quaternary International, Journal of Archaeological Science, Journal of Island and Coastal Archaeology, Quaternary Research, Archaeofauna), which demonstrate my consolidated experience in the field of Environmental Archaeology.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Sambaquis e Paisagem: Modelando a Inter-Relao entre Processos Culturais e Naturais no Litoral Sul de Santa Catarina
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Este projeto de pesquisa interdisciplinar tem como foco o estudo integrado dos processos de ocupao pr-colonial do litoral sul de Santa Catarina, com nfase nas sociedades sambaquieiras, e a evoluo concomitante dos cenrios naturais daquela regio, sobre tudo ao longo do Holoceno. Trata-se de investigar o modo pelo qual estas sociedades fizeram da regio seu territrio, interferindo ativamente na construo da paisagem litornea e imprimindo, de maneira significativa, padres culturais de carter monumental (isto , os prprios sambaquis) em meio a um ambiente natural em constante e intensa transformao, determinada por variaes do nvel do mar e pela dinmica de sistemas deposicionais costeiros marinhos, elicos e lagunares. Metodologicamente, a pesquisa decompe-se em diferentes vertentes de investigao - geolgica, antracolgica, zooarqueolgica, geofsica, biolgica e aspectos regionais e intra-stio de investigao arqueolgica - em uma abordagem sistmica, multifacetada e multidisciplinar, organizada na forma de um sistema geo-referenciado de informaes (SIG), visando elaborao de modelos integrados de evoluo ambiental e cultural, assim como micro-evoluo humana, da sociedade sambaquieira e suas relaes com sociedades contemporneas. (AU)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Este projeto de pesquisa interdisciplinar tem como foco o estudo integrado dos processos de ocupao pr-colonial do litoral sul de Santa Catarina, com nfase nas sociedades sambaquieiras, e a evoluo concomitante dos cenrios naturais daquela regio, sobre tudo ao longo do Holoceno. Trata-se de investigar o modo pelo qual estas sociedades fizeram da regio seu territrio, interferindo ativamente na construo da paisagem litornea e imprimindo, de maneira significativa, padres culturais de carter monumental (isto , os prprios sambaquis) em meio a um ambiente natural em constante e intensa transformao, determinada por variaes do nvel do mar e pela dinmica de sistemas deposicionais costeiros marinhos, elicos e lagunares. Metodologicamente, a pesquisa decompe-se em diferentes vertentes de investigao - geolgica, antracolgica, zooarqueolgica, geofsica, biolgica e aspectos regionais e intra-stio de investigao arqueolgica - em uma abordagem sistmica, multifacetada e multidisciplinar, organizada na forma de um sistema geo-referenciado de informaes (SIG), visando elaborao de modelos integrados de evoluo ambiental e cultural, assim como micro-evoluo humana, da sociedade sambaquieira e suas relaes com sociedades contemporneas. (AU)
